Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the extent to which John Cox "parroted" President Trump on separating immigrant families, as it is not clear which specific words Cox has "parroted" and there is no evidence provided to support this claim.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to demonstrate that John Cox actually "parroted" President Trump on the children's separation issues at the border.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Cox and Trump share the same words and viewpoints on the policy of separating immigrant families, without providing concrete evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim, as Cox has clearly stated his opposition to separating families and has expressed his desire to keep parents and children together.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Cox has publicly stated his opposition to separating parents and children at various occasions, including a press conference and interviews.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing clear evidence or specific examples of Cox "parroting" Trump on the issue of separating immigrant families.
Understate: The claim may understate Cox's actual stance on the issue, as it fails to acknowledge his opposition to separating families and his efforts to keep parents and children together.
